results.title: Freefall
results.creator_credit: David Stacey and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: The choreographer and dancer, Gaby Agis, has a unique style, taking dance out of the confines of the theatre and into new spaces and contexts. For this film she has taken the dance to the city, essentially London. Gaby and her Company move through narrow streets and alleys, over rooftops, constant building sites and sudden, quiet green spaces, touching in a synthesis of choreography and place only possible through film.

results.title: Freedom to read
results.creator_credit: Erik Barnouw, Center for Mass Communication of Columbia University and Julian Roffman
results.brief_description: A discussion film dealing with the problem of censorship as it affects the public library. Dramatized incidents are used in presenting opposing points of view and in raising questions regarding the role of the Library in a democratic country.

results.title: Freedom rides (A)
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Charles Perkins grew up in Alice Springs where segregation was the rule. Sent away to Adelaide for an education he became increasingly aware of the injustices perpetrated against Australian Aborigines. In 1965, the first Aborigine to attend university, he instigated the “Freedom ride” - a busload of concerned people, mostly students, who visited outback Australia, notably Walgett and Moree, to escalate the level of public awareness of racial intolerance in Australia. This video documents that journey and talks to those who took part.

results.title: Freedom or death
results.creator_credit: Christine Levy, Curtis Levy, AFFC and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Riding the tiger”.
Indonesia has one of the most militarised and organised populations in the world. From a very young age Indonesian civilians undertake training in various forms of youth groups, neighbourhood councils etc. which are all linked to the military government. In this episode the strength and power of the military is traced back to the feudal roots of Indonesia; to the resistance movements against the Dutch colonisers; the role of the Japanese army in training the Indonesians; and the underground resistance of the late 1940s which overthrew first the British occupiers of the country, then the returning Dutch administration.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christine Levy, Curtis Levy, AFFC and Olsen Levy

results.title: Freedom of the press
results.creator_credit: Irving Jacoby, Affiliated Film Producers and Alexander Hammid
results.brief_description: An historical review of freedom of the press in America from Zenger’s weekly journal to the publication of today’s newspapers. The film covers one news story (President Truman’s tax proposal) to metropolitan, small town and rural newspapers. Differentiates between news reporting and editorialising.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Irving Jacoby, Affiliated Film Producers and Alexander Hammid

results.title: Freedom is paradise = Ser swoboda eto rai
results.brief_description: Sasha Grigoriev, a 13 year old boy is an habitual escapee from the bleak reformatory in which he has been imprisoned. Sasha escapes, taking refuge with his aunt who hands him back to the authorities. There he accidentally discovers the whereabouts of his father who is serving a long prison sentence in a camp near the Arctic Circle.

results.title: Freedom in the genes
results.creator_credit: David Sington, Paula S. Apsell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Is behaviour inherited and destined since birth? This episode from the ‘Cracking the code’ series explores this question with the aid of the world’s largest gathering of twins, English sheepdogs, trained flies plus other animal assistants.
